subject: Entrepreneurship
title: The Triple Bottom Line
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Triple Bottom Line.

hook.text: In 1994, John Elkington told businesses to measure three things: people, planet, and profit.

buildup.text: He called it the triple bottom line. Boardrooms that only tracked money now had two new scorecards.

discovery.text: The idea spread fast. Over 1,000 companies adopted TBL reporting as proof they cared about more than cash.

twist.text: In 2018, Elkington recalled the concept. He said companies used it as window dressing, not real change.

climax.text: The inventor of the triple bottom line declared his own idea had failed its original mission.

punchline.text: Even great frameworks get gamed by bad actors.

quiz.question: Why did John Elkington recall his own triple bottom line concept in 2018?
options: He discovered that measuring three things was mathematically impossible
Companies were using it as PR without making genuine systemic changes
Governments passed laws making the concept illegal for reporting purposes
